Our African-American societies are certainly in the worst form ever. Never. Never. Never, "Trump said. "Take a look at the inner cities. You don't have any education. You don't have jobs. "You're shot walking down the street." The commentary soon criticized social media, as many accused Trump of having no sense of American history. We analysed Trump's comment that black American societies are "in the worst form" at all, using history and data. We will note here that African Americans continue to track white Americans in many important measures of quality of life, including economic, health and criminal justice. "A very low bar," said Bruce Levin, a historian at the University of Illinois-Champagne Urbana, who wrote about slavery and civil war. Not only do African-Americans track whites in many economic measures, but they "still face significant discrimination in employment, access to housing, mortgages and decent schools - as evidenced by the weekly headlines from almost all over the country - death, while unarmed, by the police." Joseph Borelli, a member of the New York City Council, a substitute for Trump, said something similar on CNN. "I don't think he's talking about the days of Jim Crow, even the days of the Civil Rights Movement in '60s and it's clearly not slavery," said Borelli. "But he says that African-American society is sometimes superior to other societies." If Trump had simply referred to persistent differences between black and white in economic, health and educational data, he would have a point of view. But this is very different from what he actually said. (His campaign did not respond to a request for clarification of this article.) The most obvious points corresponding to the Trump statement are more than two centuries of slavery for Americans of African descent, followed by another century of discrimination, denial of rights and aggression in the South, the region where most black people lived at the time. "African-American societies suffer from many social diseases, including poor schools and high unemployment rates, and it is important that candidates address these problems and offer specific ways to improve the situation," said Eric Funner, historian of Columbia University, who wrote many books on slavery and reconstruction after the civil war. "Anyway, it's ridiculous to say they're in the worst shape they've ever been. Put slavery aside, return to the Great Depression, or the Crack epidemic in the 1970s and 1980s." Herbert S. There is evidence of a rise in growth levels in 2015 and 2016 - neither of which is a year when final federal data are available - at least in some cities, such as Chicago and Baltimore. However, as we have noted before, the rate of homicide and violent crime has fallen significantly over the past quarter century - both in large cities and in the country as a whole - so that it will take many years of significant increases to return to "registration levels" in the early 1990s. African Americans also experienced a decrease in the number of crime victims, at least until the end of 2014, which is the final data available last year. In 2005, for example, 32.7 per 1,000 Afro-Americans aged 12 years and over were victims of a violent crime. In 2013, the rate fell to 25.1 per cent, and by 2014 it had fallen to 22.5 per cent.
